inlineContent.text: This tutorial will guide you through linking to additional resources from your documentation.
Apple use the resources section of documentation to link to videos, forums, sample code, and much more. See the bottom of Apple’s
tutorial series for an example of adding resources to documentation.
We will use the
directive to present readers with links to more documentation, forums, and sample code.
You are encouraged to build the documentation as you go through the following steps to see how the tutorial changes along the way.
Checkout the
branch in the Git repository.
Select “Meet MeetBuildABuddyKit.tutorial” in the Project navigator.
Add the
directive.
This will contain all the resources that will be presented to the readers.
Add a short description of the resources that readers can expect to find in the section.
Use the
directive to direct readers to documentation you are hosting elsewhere, for example on GitHub, or any articles that may be relevant for readers.
Select “Meet MeetBuildABuddyKit.tutorial” in the Project navigator.
Add the
directive. This directive requires a link.
The link supplied to the
directive will typically link to other documentation resources. In our case we will just link to the GitHub repository where readers can find more details about the package.
Add a short description of the documentation resources.
Add any relevant links as children of the
directive using Markdown syntax.
The links will typically direct readers to articles on getting started using the package. In our case we will link to the documentation section of the README in the BuildABuddyKit repository.
Next up we will add a section describing where readers can find communication channels.
Select “Meet MeetBuildABuddyKit.tutorial” in the Project navigator.
Add the
directive. This directive requires a link.
Typically the link should lead readers to the landing page of our forums but in this case we will link to the GitHub repository.
Add a short description of the type of communication channels.
Add links to the specific communication channels using Markdown syntax.
This is a great place to add links to a Slack, Discord, or other forums hosted on the Internet. In this case we add links to creating pull requests and opening issues for BuildABuddyKit.
Adding links to sample code is a great way to get people started using your product quickly.
In this section we will add a link to the Build a Buddy example app that we had a brief look at in the
tutorial.
Select “Meet MeetBuildABuddyKit.tutorial” in the Project navigator.
Add the
directive.
Contrary to the
and
directives, the
directive does not require a link.
Add a short description of the sample code that readers can expect to find.
Add a link to the Build a Buddy app that readers can use to explore the BuildABuddyKit package.
Finally, build the documentation to view the resources at the bottom of the landing page.

abstract.text: This tutorial will guide you through building the documentation, documenting the symbols of a type, and adding images and asides to the documentation.

abstract.text: In the previous section we learned how documentation can be written for types, properties, and functions. In this tutorial we will explore how we can add structure to our documentation.
